bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, May 27, 1875

div1.p: Reed expresses his devotion to Emilie Lawrence.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, May 27, 1875

opener.dateline:
Blacks and Whites,
Nottoway Co., Va
May 27th, 75.

div1.p:
When, a
few moments ago, I announ-
ced my intention of writing
to you, my sister exclaimed,
“my darling brother, surely
you are not going to write
to Miss Emilie again”!
She couldn't believe, that
having written on Monday,
I would write again on
Thursday! Her innocent as-
tonishment was excusable
on the basis of her non-
acquaintance with my
thoughts & feelings. As
if, for sooth, it was not
a supreme pleasure to
write even one line to you;
as if my brain would ever
grow weary with think-
ing of you, or my hand
grow tired with writing.
If circumstances compel
my absence from you, they
cannot control my pen;
and as long as this plan
of communication remains
unmolested, I shall a-
vail myself of it, and
that right often. I have
no fear that the reading
of my letters will become
irksome to you. I say this
in no spirit of selfcon-
ceit. What has selfcon-
ceit or pride to do with
my perfect confidence in
your love. With all humil-
ity I could lean my head
upon your breast, and
not so much as even
dream of any change; such
is my faith. When heart
to heart is sweetly allied,
what room is there for
haughty pride? (Permit
me to apologize for that last
rhyming sentence. It was
not my intention to afflict
you with any more verse
& not until I had finished
the sentence was I aware
of my misconduct. You can
the more easily forgive me,
as you are accredited with
the a like failing.)
In the post-script to my
last letter, I stated that cir-
cumstances might arise
which would prevent my
departure, on Saturday-
Yesterday, I received a letter
from my brother, informing
me that he would meet me
in Norfolk, on the evening
of the 29th, so that I shall
certainly go- He made a
special request of my sister,
that I should be labelled
“Norfolk, Va” & put in charge
of the conductor, lest I should
go on to Murfreesboro, and
he be disappointed for the
third time. Hence, if I fail
to appear in your town, you
will know that it is not of
my own choice. Address
your letter, Belleville, Nansemond
Co. Va care Rev. J.C. Reed. The mail goes out
on Tuesday, I think-
